bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Frederick F. Russell, July 14, 1923

div1.p: [Carter] writes about possible cases of yellow fever in Africa. He offers his opinion on the French efforts in Africa.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Frederick F. Russell, July 14, 1923
div1.opener:
/LC
I. H B
Africa
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
July 14, 1923.
Dr. F. F. Russell, General Director,
International Health Board,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.,
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
Replying to your letter of the 10th. inst., received yesterday, I
would say that the description of the case of the Italian, given by
Dr. Pettman, is--save in two points--that of yellow fever. Its devia-
tions from type are, first that he was slightly jaundiced and next that
the gums were not markedly swollen nor congested. The autposy as
given is also that of yellow fever and the fact that “the liver: kidneys
and spleen were yellow” rather implies that the slight jaundice noted a-
bove may have been due to the man being very dark or some similar reason.
In the absence of further data I would consider it yellow fever.

The same diagnosis is the most probable one in the case of Hanney--
though the history is decidedly imperfect. If this man's attack dates
from 9 A. M. April 3rd. his death at 3.30 A. M. the 6th. is unusually
early. There is frequently error, however, in determining access of
attack in a very ill patient.

I would not in general regard 2 days 7 hours from the attack as too
late to administer the serum intra-venously--though the earlier this is
done the better. Possibly the perturbation caused by the intra-venous
injection--which to my own knowledge is decidedly painful sometimes--
may have precipitated his death. Do you remember the statement of Dr.
Alva Diaz of Ferrenafe that in light cases the injection of serum (in
the muscle) was followed by immediate improvement in light cases but
seemed to hasten death in the severe ones? Possibly this latter, if
t occurred, was due to perturbation caused by the injection given
ther late in the case when any little thing of that sort will cause
cause
Russell 2
death.

Of course you must furnish both serum and vaccine for these African
outbreaks, yet I am very much afraid that--with the French especially--
they will depend on the latter to immunize their European personnel and
not do the aegypti work necessary for elimination. The fever in the
meantime will persist among the natives and we will have no information
of its occurrence. The only hope for the institution and earnest press-
ing of aegypti control in Africa is the fear of the Europeans of yellow
fever. If this be taken away or diminished by vaccination or any other
means we would despair of its elimination.
